abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is satisfactory, and
            sustainability is likely, with modest institutional
            development impacts. Key lessons address first of all, the
            need to gauge project design with the existing
            institutional, and professional capacity in the country,
            particularly in complex operations such as this one, which
            could have avoided the slow implementation start of the
            project, resulting from inadequate professional capacity,
            and inexperienced management of the various executing
            agencies involved. Road design underestimated construction
            costs, a factor which could have been avoided had detailed
            technical designs been completed prior to construction;
            moreover, based on experience, much higher financial bids
            are offered to previously estimated construction costs, when
            updated road design studies are unavailable at bidding.
            Furthermore, to ensure design quality, the terrain and
            climate conditions needs to be reviewed. As such, due to
            conditions in the Andean Mountains, full rehabilitation
            where possible, and reduced rehabilitation in critical
            zones, would have been appropriate. Performance indicators
            should be in place to monitor implementation, as well as
            institutional performance, to identify, and solve difficult
            issues early on. The absence of qualified personnel from
            executing agencies, calls for specific technical training
            programs to be developed, or, include experienced
            international consultants.
